publicationStmt.publisher: Uppsala University, Department of linguistics and philology

msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Exodus 7
ab.l:
And the Lord said to Moses, ‘See, I have made you for an angel
to Pharaoh, and Aaron your brother will be your prophet.

You shall speak to Aaron all that I command you. And
Aaron your brother shall speak to Pharaoh, that he shall send the children
of Israel from his land.

And I, I will harden Pharaoh’s heart,
and multiply my signs and
my tokens in the land of Egypt.

But Pharaoh will not listen
to you, and I will set my wrath on Egypt,
and bring out my hosts, my people, the children
of Israel, from the land of Egypt with great punishments.

And the Egyptians will know
that I am the Lord, when I reach out my wrath
on Egypt, and I will bring out the children of Israel
from among them.’

And Moses and Aaron did
as the Lord commanded them. They did so.

And
Moses was eighty years old, and Aaron eighty-three years old
when they spoke to Pharaoh.

And the Lord said
to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

‘If the Pharaoh speaks
to you, saying, “Give yourself a token,”
you shall say to Aaron, “Take your staff and cast it before
Pharaoh, and it shall become a serpent.”’

And Moses and Aaron came
to Pharaoh, and they did so as the Lord had commanded,
and Aaron cast down his staff before Pharaoh and before
his servants, and it became a serpent.

And
Pharaoh, too, called the wise men and the sorcerers; and
they, the magicians of Egypt, too, did so with their sorcery.

And they cast down every man his staff, and they
became serpents. And Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.

And Pharaoh’s heart hardened, and
he did not listen to them, as the Lord had said.

And the Lord said
to Moses, ‘Pharaoh’s heart is hardened, he does not want to let the
people go.

Go to Pharaoh in the morning. Lo, he goes out
to the water. And you shall stand opposite him by the bank of the Nile,
and you shall take the staff which was turned to a serpent
in your hand.

And you shall say to him, “The Lord God
of the Hebrews has sent me to you, saying, “Let my people go,
so that they may serve me in the wilderness.” And, lo,
you did not listen so far.

Thus says the Lord, “By this
you will know that I am the Lord: Lo, I will strike with the staff that is
in my hand on the waters which are in the Nile, and they will be turned to blood.

And the fish that are in the river will die, and the river will stink, and
the Egyptians will grow weary of drinking the water from the Nile.””’

And
the Lord spoke to Moses, ‘Say to Aaron, “Take your staff, and
reach out your hand over the waters of Egypt, over their rivers,
over their Niles, and over their lakes, and over all
the concentrations of their water, and they shall become blood. And
there shall be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, both in vessels of wood and
in vessels of stone.”’

And Moses and Aaron did so, as the
Lord commanded. And he raised the staff, and smote the
waters that were in the Nile, in the sight of Pharaoh, and in the sight
of his servants, and all the waters that were in the Nile were turned into blood.

And the fish that were in the river died, and the river stank, and
the Egyptians could not drink the water from the Nile. And there was
blood throughout all the land of Egypt.

But the magicians
of Egypt did so with their sorcery. And Pharaoh’s heart was hardened,
and he did not listen to them, as the Lord had said.

And
Pharaoh turned and came into his house, and he did not pay attention
even to this.

And all the Egyptians dug around
the Nile for water to drink, because they could not drink
from the Nile’s waters.

And seven days were filled
after the Lord had punished the Nile.

And
the Lord spoke to Moses, ‘Come to Pharaoh, and say to him,
“Thus says the Lord, “Let my people go, so that they may
serve me.

And if you are not willing to let go,
lo, I will smite all your borders with frogs.

And the river will breed frogs, which will go up and come even in your house,
and in your bedchamber, and on your bed, and
in the house of your servants, and on your people, and in your ovens, and
in your bread-leavening vessels.

And the frogs will come up on you,
and on your people, and on all your servants.””’
